110
imaginary picture, but what has taken place
in the United States, & by no very abstruse train of
reasoning will be seen in Texas. The little Farmers
about here cultivate or "raise" cotton enough for their
own use, which the females of the family card, &
spin for clothing & with deer skins that men
make their hunting & working dresses -
15th. Started & got to L__ settlement & next day to dinner were we had been regaled with
the 'Boars' flesh & Sasafras Tea x. when the
crossed out: identical same sort of report was again set before us. 

The heavy rains had swelled the creeks, and

at Cypress Bayou, & there being no Ferry, had
to crossed out: amuse ourselves by Swimming swim it.  It being
a hot day the dipping was a comfortable bath.

 Arrived at Houston in the Afternoon - 

On the road met the Courier or Post man*, or Mail-rider
he gave us a paper containing an account of the 
fight at Lipantitlan [[crossed out: which I cut out and 
present to my readers.]]
x The Yaupon leaves - to my taste make a better
Substitute for Tea.

112. 
18. I called on His Excellency the President & Congress 
is still in session - 
19. Left Houston for Galveston. here once more I
enjoyed the cool & grateful Sea-breeze. Things are
looking very flat. "Poverty is staring us in the faces,
our Imports exceed our Exports this year, our 'difficulties'
are very pressing." The Congress has not adjourned,
but all important business has been gone into. The War
bill, with its amendments by the opposition gives the President
more power than he believes judicious to exercise,
and it is supposed that he will Vitoe it, on the
grounds of unconstitutionality. So prior to this
government that the 6X per day cannot be paid to
the Members of Congress - Exchequer Bills may be
paid but they are at 70% discount. The time
will come when Members of Congress will not
requires that their expenses be paid by the Treasury.
23. General Cañales, crossed out:  ( a base traitor to Texas x why dont he pay his debts in Galveston?)  who
headed the Lipantitlan Marauders, has crossed out: long had
it in contemplation to form a 'Northern Mexican
Republic!  But General Arista coquetted
crossed out:  some time & brought Cañales round to Santana's views
x This too referred to the period when ? & many Texan
Volunteers went to arrest him

Vol III Cop: I
1
Through the unremitting exertions of General Hamilton Texas was recognized by England in Nov. 1840 & previously to this period the General has the honor of negociating [sic]  the treaties of recognition with France, Belgium & Holland.  It was hoped by these recognitions that Gl. H. would have been able to have negociated a Loan for Texas, but the general financial crisis & some other causes prevented this, thus Gl. H. left Europe [crossed out: after]]  & passing through the United States, presented himself at Austin.  The Congress was about adjourning, a New President & his administration now held power and altho Gl H had rendered important diplomatic service to his newly adopted country, his not being successful in financial matters caused his reception in Austin to be anything but flattering.   Gl. H. left Texas for Carolina to join his family from whom he had been seperated some time, with the idea of returning shortly to Texas when he should have arranged his private affairs in the States. X  
X June1842.  It is said that some [?]  took place at Austin between Gl. H. & W. K. that the Gl has sent him a challenge to England & he followed it

Under LaMars administration Mr. A. Ikin of London has been appointed Texan Consul for that city, but with Gl. Houstons re-entry into power a Mr. Barnes at the instance of Mr Jones (of the firm of Northland & Jones of Galveston) had been appointed in Mr Ikins place, but the appointment of Mr. Kennedy to the office of Consul General for Gt. Britain, gave offence to Mr. Jones & this gentleman somewhat pettily begged to have Mr. Barnes' name withdrawn

  France for some time past had its representative in M. Saligny as Minister, x with a French Consul in Galveston.
  Belgium sent an agent in the person of Captn Pierson to communicate with the Govt -  this Gentleman after visiting Austin made a journey through part of the Western country & suggested that a colony of Belgians might be established on the Rio Grande in which the Texas Gov acquiesced.  Capt P. returned to Europe to give an account of his mission.
  The Whig Ministry in England during the Elections saw that the Tories or Conservatives would have a considerable majority, consequently they must retire from office &  during the last fleeting moments

Saligny found it necessary to retire for awhile to New Orleans - The President La Mer being sick, the Vice President Barnett acted & suggested thro the Texas Minister in Paris the removal of M. Saligny.  This the French Govt. did not acquiesce in, requested M. S. to remain in Texas & sent him the grade of officer with Legion of Honor.

of Mexico imprisoned as felons laden with chains, obliged to work in the streets of that capital & other places, produced in Santana & his ? so exhilirating an effect that Mexican bombast was not long in declaring itself ready to annoy at least the Texan frontier. (appendix II)

  Early in 1842 Mr Wm Kennedy author of "The Rise Progress & Prospects"   paid Texas a second visit, to purchase lands.  The Govt conferred upon this gentleman the Consul Generalship to Great Britain, & at the same time allotted him grants of land upon certain conditions (see Appendix III) to the S & W of San Antonio, upon the Rivers Frio, Leon & down to the Nueces, taken in a grant upon the Rio Grande.
  The same sort of grants were made to M. Wm Castro with the Texan Consul Generals [?] to France. *   Messrs Kenedy & Castro returned to Europe to attend to these matters & who would thus intrust themselves to provide useful & hospitable colonists.

Shortly after his appointment certain circumstances connected with M. Castro prompted M. Saligny to request his Govt not to grant M. C. His ? & moreover he was removed from the Consulship for France.

Ashbel Smith was appointed Minister Plenipotentiary to France with the function of exchanging the Treaty with England, accompnd by Mr. Tenlon as  head of Legation.

 For some time past - it may be said for the last six years - Texas had been threatened with invasion & annihilation by Mexico.    Texas had tried but in vain by long honorable & equitable means to come to an amicable adjustment.  By Sea invasion was impossible, for Mexico had no fleets in activity, & the little but effective Texas Squadron was found sufficient to assist Yucatan and blockade the Enemys posts.

[in left margin is written Houston]

  The Congress having adjourned, the President & principal members of the Govt being at Galveston  information arrived that large bodies of Mexicans had crossed the Rio Grande.  It  was officially confirmed on the 10th March that the enemy was in the country.  The excitement was very great, some supposing that a serious Mexican war was now upon the Eve of bursting forth - although Gl. Houston did not entertain this view of the subject.  Nevertheless the regular army was in motion; every citizen putting

3
himself in a position to dispute every inch of ground with the Enemy.  The Mexicans had advanced as far as San Antonio distributing a Proclamation signed by General Arista, the composition of which /Appendix A/ showed how little he knew of the Texan character, supposing that they would now submit to Santana.  With this military ? of the Enemy it was reported & credited by many, that this was the advanced guard of some 15 or 20.000 men.
[written in left margin: Houston]

  At the same time it was reported that three Mexican transports were off the coast laden with Arms &c to be conveyed via Copano to the Mexican Army.
  The Government coffers were empty, but the patriotism^ & munificent donations of the Citizens of Galveston and others equipped the Steamer "Lafitte" and two small craft to go on the coast to intercept the said transports.  This expedition was under the command of Capt. J. Wade manned by a part of the Galveston Coast Guards x - the Galveston Fusiliers cooperating.  Thus on the 14th March this expedition put to Sea.  It cruised in & about the Bays

X called the "Red Rovers" from wearing Red Shirts.

until the 30th. when it appeared that just now the trumpeted Invasion was confined to some 800 or 1000 Men having accompanied Aristas proclamation; leaving the people in the West & retiring quicker than they came.  A party under Gonzales surprised Capt. Karnes & five of his companions. Killed them all save  D. Cameron who escaped.  as a [?] set off to this murder.  Three Mexican Spies were taken, two of whom were hung at Head Quarters.

  On the news of Mexican invasion reaching the U. States, volunteers armed & equipped started immediately for Galveston proceeding to the Main Army under Gl. Burleson.  The recollection of Mexican barbarity, with the treatment of the Santa Fe' prisoners was sufficient to so [?] the Southerners to assist their Texas brethren with the 1 body & were directed five of their never erring rifles.
[Houston written in left margin]
  The 26th March Gl. Houston issued his motion of blockade of the Mexican ports from Matamoros to Tabasco Appendix III & moreover gave orders (Appendix IV) that each county should arm & equip its quota of men in all about 3 to 6000 Men to be ready to rendezvous with the Main Army & Volunteers at a moment's notice.

4

  Thus the country would be now in a comparative good state of defence & upheld although under great struggles by the patriotism and  [[?ortion?] of its citizens.
  The retur'g Austin proclamation had the effect of putting a stop of agricultural affairs in the west & many farmers left their lands, not deeming it safe to remain, but the produce of the cotton crops was not affected & some 80 to 90,000 bales were exported.   There is no doubt but it had some injury to colonization for the moment from the States & England & measurably affected commercial relations with Europe.
 Party spirit ran high against the Executive, on the part of those who had just left power - they wishing to invade Mexico instanter.  But for the object funds were requested & a large armed force, this was not practicable.
 The Texan navy returned from Yucatan having been paid some 35,000$ went to N. Orleans to refit & [?let?] in fresh Men.  Three Small Mexican vessels were taken & sent to Galveston.

[Houston written in left margin]

116
September 14th.  At no period has the extreme political horizon of Texas looked so clear (same as regards Mexico) or its position among nations better.  Texas has been recognized by the U. States, France, England, Holland, Belgium, Rome & negotiations in this point are going on with the Hanseatic States.  From England especially when the state be at peace with Mexico - her manufacturers and Emigrants will pour in.  Although this country has passed Y is still passing through a painful ordeal, yet produce has increased & the returns of Galveston from Jany [January] to July gives a considerable item in favor of exports.  After the Battle of St. Jacinto the majority of citizens sheathed the Sword & took to the plough.  Those many of who came form the U. States or Volunteers found it not to send them to settle down in the country returned to their homes.   Yet a Military or War party existed & when out of power, they have been accused of acts of turbulence.  The Navy of late found employment in assisting the Yacatecos.  The outs in Texas live on, & love "excitement" & this opposition partakes at times of factious violence.  When the Mexicans entered San Antonio in the Spring, the War Party was up in Arms and 'onward' was their cry.  The President discountinanced as much as he was able

violent belligerent demonstrations.  1st there may have been good political reasons - 2. The Treasury was Empty 3 What credit had Texas ? None. 21.  A Brig with a White flag at her fore & a Mexican flag at her pique came in bringing he rest of the Santa Fe' prisoners with Genl McLeod, 10 days from Vera Cruz (14 of those liberated prisoners had died of Black Vomit at Vera Cruz).  The Brig came to anchor 3 miles below the Town.  There were some 183 or more huddled together.  I went on board, it was in the evening, they appeared like a dense sluggishly moving mass;  all severely sun burnt, & wretchedly clad.  The effluence on board was unpleasant indeed & it was reported that there was a case of black Vomit.  Captain Halliday one of those who escaped from Fannons massacre had died in the passage.  Some observed that they

had enough of such expeditions, & some said "they were ready for another!  It appears that about one third of the party was killed by Mexicans & Indians & died of sickness some    50 have remained in Mexico, but liberated, 3 entered the Mexican Service!

  There was a Meeting this Evening to pursue means to clothe the poor fellows.  Everyone ransacked his wardrobe in tanta?s for this purpose.
  When first this expedition was planned it was intended to have sent at least 1000 Men so as to be prepared for any emergency.  There was so much delay, X that Santa Ana had time to strengthen Sta Fe' with troops, he believing that the Texan Traders intended to revolutionize that part of Mexico.  Less than one-half the original number proceeded to cross the Wilderness; had they not gone astray on their route & arrived in health & spirits, the Mexican force under Governor Armijo could not have made them prisoners; but Lewis' treason filled up the Measure of the unfortunate unit? exit? of it.   They expedition did not pursue the route they proposed, they got lost, bewildered & dispirited.  They  separated from each other, finding themselves opposed by very superior armed force, they

X owing mainly to the congress comending with General La Mar in his view upon the matter, but not appropriating funds for this expedition.

121
faded writing  Observations of Mr Maillard's History of Texas
[Notes in pencil written in left margin:  Kennedy's 10/    Ask Polly to gate?    Maillards Work 5/ - ]]

Doran Maillard "Barrister at Law in Texas" somehow or another in his return to Europe after a short residence in Texas - (among his other operations was received as a Barrister) This honor he boasts in all probability has found difficult to attain in his own country.  He returns to Europe, writes his history of Texas, but not the History of the Country.  The Old Spanish proverb of " Dime con quien andas, yo te dire quien eres' explains at least to any enquiring person the reasons he had in emanating his work under the patronage of the Mexican Govt.  I mention here the subject of a commemoration by him against not very favorable to Texas, read to the Geographical Society of London in 1840 - & by each to his mind the discipline that arose out of that production & the not very favorable personal remarks made  on side to Mr M. by a member of the Society.   If he has  forgotten - this may bring it back to his recollection.   I might fill pages in showing the untruths & vindictiveness contained in his work, but refer 1st to what he says when speaking of Texas Latins.  Mr. M. could never have been admitted into the Society of Texas ladies, or he would not accuse them of smoking pipes.  That Mr. M. might have seen some gude auld wife, in the back woods whiffing at a corn cob pipe I will not deny - Has Mr M ever travelled in Wales, or some parts of Yorkshire, to say nothing of auld Ireland

type_os: JPEG image data, JFIF standard 1.01, resolution (DPI), density 300x300, segment length 16, Exif Standard: [TIFF image data, little-endian, direntries=6, manufacturer=Canon, model=Canon EOS-1Ds Mark III, software=Adobe Photoshop Camera Raw 6.6 (Macintosh),

element_texts.text: Completed

122
if not I beg to inform him that I have seen Farmer's wives & others smoking their pipe in England.

  When an informer to the "Swab" I have never seen it used in Texas by ladies.  I have in the West Indies & a piece of the proper sort of wood makes an excellent apology for a tooth brush - but as to snuff being generally used - O fie on you Mr. M. none of it had been so - When in your gallantry to the sea - in a subsequent journey noticed this only once.
  Now with regard to the Hotels.  I confess that the accommodation occasionally met with is not quite so recherchê as at Fantons or Longs, but in the principal towns I have been in such as Galveston, Houston, Matagorda, Swartwout, Austin, Brazos, or Gonzales, Sn. Antonio &c &c I have been perfectly contented with the accommodation offered, & this someone during a period that was not for the moment so flourishing as when Mr. M. was in the country.   It was probably my good fate to make the acquaintance of hospitable planters & other persons in the Country & whilst honestly I have informed ? my kindness.

type_os: JPEG image data, JFIF standard 1.01, resolution (DPI), density 300x300, segment length 16, Exif Standard: [TIFF image data, little-endian, direntries=6, manufacturer=Canon, model=Canon EOS-1Ds Mark III, software=Adobe Photoshop Camera Raw 6.6 (Macintosh),

element_texts.text: Completed

123

 Then with regard to the the Killing of the Indians Mr. M. says 8000 perished during the Mexican & Texan Revolutions - Preposterous!  I beg to inform Mr. M. that the Mexican Revolution commenced about the year 1810 - What number of Indians were killed from that time until 1831-2 when the Texan Revolution commenced, must be subtracted at least from the 8000.  I suppose I must confess I am not sentimental enough to be ever repeating "O the Poor Indians! O the poor Red Man!  The Natural possessors of the Soil! &c &c"  But may observe that for their own sakes it is a pity they do not become agriculturally inclined - then a smaller quantity of land, would administer more rationally to their wants; industry would assist in utilizing them.   They would no more be the amanb? indolent Wanderers, nor require so much territory for their hunting incursions.
  The intercourse between them and the White Man would then be what it ought to be & the Red Man in time would become a useful member of society.  At present, they are mere hunters that take advantage of them.  some of the Indian Chiefs in Texas are

element_texts.text: Completed

124
intelligent men speaking English & Spanish & with proper Management & in time many of the Indian tribes in Texas may be released from the Savage state.   I need hardly mention how the progress towards a state of civilization the Cherokees in the U.S. are advancing.   They were doing the same in Texas, had their farms & Stock when the wars commenced & moreover the [symbol referring to marginal note:  Cherokee were found to be in communication with the enemy.] which ended at the death of 'Bowles 'Egg"* & other Chiefs & a dispersion of the tribes  [X symbol referring to marginal note:  I may observe that of late treaties have been made with all the Indian tribes in Texas excepting the Comanches, & ere long it is expected to have a treaty with them.]

  Mr. M. says in another part that there are no roads in Texas (excepting natural ones) The Old Spaniards, Mexicans & the present occupiers of the soil have cut many roads, & at great expense,  I have travelled from Houston to Swartwout on a carriage road, east through Pine woods -  Is there not a carriage road from the Rio Grande through the whole of [symbol referring to marginal note:  Texas by Nacogdoches into the United States.]  Roads are made through forests by finding the direction by a compass from say from one Town to another - then commencing in that ?, Cutting pieces off with a axe from the Sides of Trees at that time - this is called 'Blazing" &



Chief Bowles aka 'Egg'

type_os: JPEG image data, JFIF standard 1.01, resolution (DPI), density 300x300, segment length 16, Exif Standard: [TIFF image data, little-endian, direntries=6, manufacturer=Canon, model=Canon EOS-1Ds Mark III, software=Adobe Photoshop Camera Raw 6.6 (Macintosh),

element_texts.text: Completed

125
removing the intermediate trees.  I must own that the Texan forest roads would be better for sundry stumps taken away  & Macadamized.  but the roads or tracks on the Prairie in dry weather are excellent.  A friend of mine went the other day from Houston to Austin, then on to St Antonio & to the Nueces & from there to Galveston in a Buggy.  Indeed with few exceptions the greater portion of the country can be traveled in pretty direct lines by Waggons and karts or how ? the settlers move onwards -

  I have considered it a duty on my part to have made the above observations relative to Mr. M. view of things in Texas - And in conclusion will add that we must [crossed out: have] seen through a different medium.  (If request Review Mr. Maillards Book)
faded writing, barely legible (See Warfields? on the Tales of California? part II. 17th ? - ? )

125

 Every now & then the the subject of California and the Oregon territory is wanted even here in Texas & affords points for interesting discussion.  The unfortunate circumstances connecting the Santa Fe' expedition have drawn the attention of some of the Missouri traders & trappers to Santa Fe & California in retaliation against certain Governor Armigo of Santa Fe' on account of the sufferings of their countrymen.  We are informed that the far west is a "glorious country" and remain afraid that if the Americans get a footing in the N & N.W. Mexican ?ns? upon whatever be the pretext there will be a "difficulty" to get them out.
  An expedition is at present forming under a Mr. Warfield with the sanction of President Houston the object being to come into Texas by the Missouri trail with say 400 Men into the vicinity of Santa Fe' & then commence retaliation such as appropriating [?] & take the Mexican Caravans Hordes & catch goods &c.   The opposition disdains against this proceeding & flatly call it a robbery.
  (See Civilians & Mr. Turbouts observations May 6 1843)  It would appear that there has been a collision between Friisilegs? party & some U. States dragoons near the Arkansas & Texas line

126  During the Spring assizes, it was expected that there would be a very interesting trial, namely of a woman for the murder of her husband.  The case was that the husband had given her cause to be jealous upon which in a paroxysm of jealous rage - she shot him.   The Coroners inquest found her guilty of Murder & she was incarcerated until the Assizes should open.*    Judge Morriss opened the court - then followed the entry of Mexicans into San Antonio, the Judge, gentlemen of the bar & the principal officers of Court were off to the Army - the Woman who was about to be tried for Murder, was bailed - she went up the country to her friends - & in all probability when called upon would be 'Non inventus.'

   The following occurred in Galveston lately - A ? one whose brother had been hung for murder in the U.S. & he himself had the ? X  Violent record of a fellow was beating his wife early one morning.  An industrious citizen was passing by on the way to his Store, when the woman cried out for help to him as he was passing by requesting him to go for the Sheriff.   The husband immediately ran out, plunged a Knife into the individual passing, some neighbors rescued him - a Surgeon was sent for and dressed his

X An ould Baig? Barg? that had run us home? in a 'Norther' was the prison - The person who had charge of this died & no one was found willing to combine his offices - thus we are without any place of confinement to the utter disconsolation of our worthy Sheriff  This I have often hear say 'O for the laws cannot be made to be respected without a gaol'.

Introduction Obs:  on the Courts of Law by by Judge Thompson.  On the afternoon of the 20th - news arrived in Galveston of the following tenor.
It is ? Known? reported that could General Woll have crossed the Colorado ^ which he could not owing to the waters he would have marched to Austin, taken away its inhabitants and probably destroyed the Archives.

  In these Southern countries, the dead are soon entomed - a few hours only in some cases after the vital spark has fled.  It would appear that a man in the town of Galveston named _______

128
had been seized with congestive fever.  A medical man was called in, who ordered among other things in his prescription some aspirin, but pronounced  the case to be a very bad one.  At the expiration of a few hours, the patient appeared to his friends to be dead.   The baches? was went for, shown the corpse, & it was laid out on a Carpenters bench, envelopped  in a shroud.  The friends of the defunct retired to a lower room to recruit their spirits with a 'drink'  They had done all that they were able, & now awaited the arrival of the Coffin.   They recounted, all the good qualities of he deceased, for he had been in many a fight during the revolution - And his death was not a very melancholy one.  Not being a married man  - & his relatives not known to his friends.   A. Wag presents could not help drinking him a safe journey to Heaven.  On this being drunk - a noise was heard in the upper room as if some  one had fallen on the floor.

 'By _____" said one of the party "David has fallen down'
 'Fallen down'! replied another somewhat scared

Reserrection. - We understand that a Mr. Haskins, of Galveston, was taken suddenly sick a day or two since, and died, as was supposed by his friends, with the yellow fever.  He was regularly laid out, leads placed  on his eyes, &c., and a short time after he came rushing down stairs almost frightened out of his wits, declaring that there was a ghost in his room.  He is now rapidly recovering and will probably be well in a few days.   - Telegraph

type_os: JPEG image data, JFIF standard 1.01, resolution (DPI), density 300x300, segment length 16, Exif Standard: [TIFF image data, little-endian, direntries=6, manufacturer=Canon, model=Canon EOS-1Ds Mark III, software=Adobe Photoshop Camera Raw 6.6 (Macintosh),

element_texts.text: Completed

129
'How the devil can a dead man fall about"?   A stifled groan was heard - All started on their legs - when pat, pat, pat, something came down stairs, when to their horror and astonishment David - their friend whom they had supposed dead - stepped into the lower room wrapt up in his shroud - looked at them most piteously points to his parched tongue with his left fore finger, extending his right hand  out & in a weak voice said 'Give me some brandy and Water'  'Tis his ghost they all exclaimed' and ran out of the house.  David - set himself down & helped himself to the brandy & water & his own 'funeral baked meats', when after a interval, one by one his friends came to the door and saw that David was alive - He recovered perfectly & has been in good health ever since.
This is the fact of this case.  WB

133

 Another news we get from Mexico comes trumpeting that by sea & land we may momentarily expect to be invaded.
  Should this "consumation devoutly to be wished' come off - By land the Texans are ready for the enemy - Galveston island is getting into a State of defense under Col. Hockly, & the Volunteers of the City.   Nature has been kind enough to form natural trenches, on the Sea Shore of Sand, from behind these should an enemy land there would be at least without any enforcements 600 Rifles ready to welcome them, and no want of Artillery -
     Santa Ana must have sufficient to employ himself just now - the capital to keep in military order - political & military discontents to coquette with.   The United States claims - the disobedience of Yucatan & Texas to chastise & lastly the ambiguous tenure by which he holds his Dictatorial position.   ? late military promenade, increased in carrying away some defenseless inhabitants from San Antonio - In this he was assisted by the Traitor Saguin, this last having been personally concerned in butchering Dawsons Company of Lafayette Volunteers.  With squadrons pushing on to the Colorado, with hope of crossing that stream, then marching upon Austin sacking it & burning the Archives - but he was afraid to cross the Colorado for many coûtes que coûtes & for fear of being hemmed in by the Texans

[lines drawn through this paragraph]   
is said about 'Boucher' was a sort of façon de parler.  For I have the honor to Know both Joseph, Jerome & Seneca - and was once at Sr. Albans in England at Joseph Bonaparts House & have visited him in London' -
'Bien Monsieur - mais non pas Boucher' -

 According to his account he was the Son of a person named Duval, an illegitimate offspring of Napoleon's - who married in the island of Guadalupe & had served under Napoleon in the Army.   That in Napoleon's exile to Santa Helena, Duval contrived to get there, but was soon discovered and sent away from the island, this broke Duval's heart & he died!
 The Widow & family returned to the United States, the sons becoming Merchants!
 I returned to Galveston by the same road I had come, & found that place in a great hubbub.  Letters have been received from N. Orleans stating that A dozen or more Steamers, Men of War & Transports were fitting out at Vera Cruz for the invasion of Texas, & that Galveston would be the first place of disembarkation.  But the old Stagers - believed that this Fleet was rather destined for Yucatan & if successful there why then they might pay Texas a ^ visit

18th   The last Congress offered the  President almost dictatorial powers - he veto'd the bill to that effect as unconstitutional.  Some went so far to say that the Congress wished to  commit him. He remained in Houston some time, oftimes personally suffering in his finances.

  The President then for reasons best known to himself, removed the Seat of Govt to Washington on the Brazos & went there with his Lady.   The Secretary of War and Marine Col. Hackly resigned, emptying the Command at Galveston.  The President it is reported has it in contemplation, finding that the Volunteer Chiefs will not obey him to organize a standing army of 5000 men.  the cost of putting  this number in the field will be 250,000$ & the 150,000 per annum, the private soldier pay being at 8$ per month.
 The following on the particulars of the top of the 'Merchant' Steamer from N. Orleans to Galveston.

139
November.  Many persons having families are leaving Galveston, fearing that Galveston may be attacked.  
7th  Letters arrived from Velasco at night-fall saying that a Fleet of vessels with Steamers in Company was supposed to have been seen off that port.  All the Volunteers obeyed the Tocsin, which was rung at the Presbyterian  Church - The different companies formed under their respective officers & the greater part of them occupied all night in getting Col. Hockleys boat on the East end of the island in order in case there should be any truth in the report.  Anxiously we watched the mornings Inivns? of the 8th  I accompanied                Sempter? the Pilot to the Beacon, he climbed to the top, waited then until it was broad day light - But no signs of the enemy.
11th  The 'New York' Steamer brought us news that the Steamer fleet composed of 10 Sail had left Vera Cruz for Yucatan, with promissas to come to Galveston after the rebel Yucatecas are brought to their duty.   The Texan Squadron are there at N. Orleans & without the means to get to Sea.  The Summer had left us & it is getting cold.   N.W. Gales set in, now we have the commencement of winter.

  The British Government has ordered home all the British officers & Seamen now in the Mexican Service - this act is a Battle ground for Texas.

27th  The Mexican Government talking of sealing certain claims of the United States Government, so as to keep the Yankees quiet.  Santa Ana was at his Hacienda

of 'Manga de Clavo" awaiting his time to return to the city of Mexico with the Rod of iron & punish the Malcontents - i.e. the Federal party of Patriots, but his success will not be very great, if his Army is not supplied before Yucatan.

  With no business doing this all those who are fond of shooting & Hunting have ample means of enjoying themselves.

Decr 6.  Whilst out hunting - camped out at "Doker Point' Galveston bay - the weather had been warm for the last five days, & as this spot passed 'una noche horrosa' on account of mosquitos.
18.  The English Yacht 'Dolphin' Capt. Houston arrived from England.  Capt. H. intends to purchase lands & form a settlement, he has not decided upon the whereabouts yet-
Dec or Jan 1847 The following
X of the Firm of Rickards [[Litch?]} & Co

November - It would appear that Generals Woll & Ampudia are hovering about our frontier. Awaiting any opportunity to make incursions.   The President at last (to keep piece [sic] at home) has appointed General Somerville to Command the Volunteers ^ in their march going toward  - (but there is some confusion in our camp - At last our army started, capturing Laredo Dec 8th & Guerrero (and under consultation over all believing his force inadequate to do more wished now to return homewards -Fisher was appointed Commanding officer over those who remained.  Fisher entered Mier but ultimately had to capitulate having fought a terrible fight
Vide Commencement of 1843

No IIII from Jany to August 6th
January 1843. General festivities to [torn page] New Year.

  The last Congress offered President Houston dictatorial powers.  It has been observed that in so doing some wished to see if he would accept, for it was presumed he wont commit himself.  But the President saw through the maneuver and put his veto upon the bill.
  General Houston considered it convenient to remove the Seat of Government to Washington on the Brazos, as being more protected than Austin & more central than Houston.  Washington was originally intended for the Seat of Government

March 2nd Anniversary of Texan independence.

 The declaration of Independence was publicly read in the Presbyterian church by Mr. Stewart, and an historical oration by Mr. Merriman.
 Public dinners & Balls in the Evening.
 The news from Yucatan informs us that Santana's army is getting the worst of it.   The federal party in Mexico oppose Santa Anna & wish to come to some terms with Texas.

March 20th.  Under this date I find amongst my notes an extract from an official communication from the Texan Minister to the Government of the United States, when speaking of the failure of entering into a communal treaty with the United States X
[note in margin:]  X  "that the treaty had failed - Slander has performed its office!  its work is complete."  This is attributed to the "War Party".
The result is that the Texan government has put an additional duty ad valorem of five per cent on all goods imported in foreign bottoms? with the exception of those foreign vessels which by treaty or act of Congress are permitted to enter on payment of the domestic duty"

  Thus Texas having no Commercial Treaty with the United States is now obliged to pay five per cent more duty than England, France, Belgium, Holland & the Hanseatic States.  Moreover the tonnage dues on the Steamers from New Orleans was increased.

element_texts.text: Completed

newspaper clipping
Indians Suing for Peace.  The President has received a message from James Logan, Agent for the Creek Indians in Arkansas, conveying the pleasing intelligence that at the late meeting of the tribes  called together in the Creek nation by Roly McIntosh, to establish amicable relations with each other, several chiefs from Texas attended.  Among these were Now-no-hitch-tow-e, head chief of the Keachies, Ki-ki-see-no-hah, chief of a tribe residing on the Wichita, and Sar-powe-e, head chief of the Towaccanies. - They stated that they were all desirous to make peace with the Texians; and that several of the prairie tribes of Texas, including the Commanches, were also anxious for peace.  They stated that they had been at war with the Texians for several years, and were tired of hostilities, and would long since have sent in a flag of truce to our settlers, but were fearful that they would be shot down.  Mr. Logan further states, that they desire that Gen. Houston should designate a time and place to meet them, to form a treaty of peace. - They say that all the tribes of Texas, except a few renegade Cherokees, will send deputies to meet him at any place on the frontier that he may designate, and they think all the tribes residing on our borders, will readily join in concluding the treaty. - [Telegraph.

Santanas proposition for an Armistice or peace ! -
Under 26th March Vide Obs. ^ a Journal on Texan fleet & its operation at leaving New Orleans for Yucatan.

Important effects produced by Commodore Moore
1st. He has beaten off the Mexican Fleet from before Yucatan causing at best much ?ying to the Montezuma. & daring them to approach the coast -  Had he had but the Steamer to have brought him into action the Mexican Squadron would have been taken.
2. Moore has raised the siege of Yucatan - he has given confidence to the brave Yucaticos, Medez? has discovered the cunning and falsity of Ampudia & thus the Mexican General must capitulate.
3.  Moore will have prevented the Transports with enforcements from joining Ampudia & will in all probability make prizes of them
4.  Thus was my look upon Santanas operation against Yucatan as having failed - And moreover ^ the most important point no invasion of Texas at least by Sea can take place

It has been warm during the month.  on the  15th at 8 am. 81º.  2 pm 83º. 9 pm 82º.  The Mean of temperatures of Galveston from April 1842 to April 1843 was at 8 am. 66º. 02  2 pm 70º 60.  9 pm 66º 80

  The Mean annual temperature for above time 67º . 90.  That of St. Petersburg 39º. Rome 60º.  Paris 70º

element_texts.text: Completed

June 1.  Under date of 20th April General Santana provisional President, or Dictator of Mexico: notified to the Foreign Ministers in Mexico that he will not answer the claims made in favor of foreign emigrants made prisoners by Mexican soldiers, that they would be treated as enemies & punished accordingly - moreover that Foreign consuls in Texas will not be allowed any other rights than neutral foreigners - and even this Santa Anna calls a concession.   The Foreign Ministers protested against this, and the Texans look upon it as another specimen of Mexican bombast.
crossed out:  General Murphy arrives in Texas as Minister from the United States.

June 20.  President Houston has had faith in the good offices of England - he has signed the proclamation for an armistice with Mexico dated Washington 15th inst.
Neither Monsieur Cramayel*  or General Murphy can feel very much complemented in relation to it.   Why did not the U. States come out boldly long since & nurse  its offspring?   Oh no, that did not suit.   Why did not the U. States enter into a Commercial treaty with Texas?  Why Jonathan likes to play possum.  "Verimos con el tiempo' as the Spaniards say.
Proclamation


Viscount J. de Cramayel
